front.title: Modeling the Digital Map based on RFC8345: Sharing Experience

abstract.t: This document shares experience in modelling digital map based on the IETF RFC8345 topology YANG modules and some of its extensions. It also shares the open issues encountered during the modelling phase of the Digital Map.

note.name: Discussion Venues
note.t: Source for this draft and an issue tracker can be found at .

section.name: Introduction
section.t: The is a topology based YANG model with many extensions for different technologies and service types. The modelling approach based on provides the out of box standard IETF based API.

At the time of writing those lines, there are 60 YANG Modules augmenting , 59 IETF and 1 BBF. 8 have maturity level 'ratified', 15 have maturity level 'adopted', 21 have maturity level 'latest-approved' and 16 have maturity level 'initial'. The up to date information can be found in the YANG Catalogue at .
From this long series of IETF RFCs and IETF drafts, we attempted to create a Digital Map PoC, with the following objectives and functionality:

ul.li: Modelling of digital map entities, relationships, and rules how to build aggregated entities and relationships. Basically evaluating how well the different drafts fit together
Modelling multiple underlay/overlay layers from L2 to customer service layer
We based our modelling on and we successfully modelled the following using this approach:

section.t: - L2 Network Topology (used )
- L3 Network Topology (used )
- OSPF Routing (to be further aligned with )
- IS-IS Routing (to be further aligned with )
- BGP Routing
- MPLS LDP
- MPLS TE Tunnels
- SRv6 Tunnels
- L3 VPN Services
This draft documents our experience implementing the modelling a real network with the topology YANG modules model and its extensions.
While we progress our Digital Map PoC, we want to share our experience and some open issues encountered.
During the PoC, we also defined the requirements and verified the PoC approach by demoing it iteratively.

section.name: Terminology
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "NOT RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

dl.dd: Modelling the Digital Map using the IETF approach, by defining the supported network types (layers and sublayers), entity types, entity roles (network, node, tp or link), entity properties and relationships types between entities.

A basis for the Digital Twin that provides a virtual instance of the topological information of the network. It provides the core multi-layer topology model of the digital twin that defines the core topological entities, their role in the network, core properties and relationships both inside each layer and between the layers. It is the basic topological model that is extended with other functional parts of the digital twin and connects them all: configuration, maintenance, assurance (KPIs, status, health, symptoms), traffic engineering, different behaviours, simulation, emulation, mathematical abstractions, AI algorithms, etc

as defined in , it as 'a virtual instance of a physical system (twin) that is continually updated with the latter’s performance, maintenance and health status data throughout the physical system’s life cycle'.

section.name: Digital Map Intro and how it relates to Digital Twin
What is Digital Twin?
section.t: The digital twin concepts and the reference architecture of the network digital twin are proposed in the NMRG draft . This draft defines the Digital Twin as 'a virtual instance of a physical system (twin) that is continually updated with the latter’s performance, maintenance and health status data throughout the physical system’s life cycle'.

The draft also states that a digital twin network can be regarded as an indispensable part of the overall network system and provides a general architecture involving the whole life cycle of physical networks in the future, serving the application of innovative network technologies such as network planning, construction, maintenance and optimization, improving the automation and intelligence level of the network.

The draft defines the core elements of digital twin – Data, Models, Interfaces and Mapping. The digital twin network constructed based on the four core technology elements can analyze, diagnose, emulate, and control the physical network in its whole life cycle with the help of optimization algorithms, management methods, and expert knowledge

section.name: Digital Map Definition
section.t: Digital Map provides the core multi-layer topology model and data for the digital twin and connects them to the other digital twin models and data.
The Digital Map Model defines the core topological entities, their role in the network, core properties and relationships both inside each layer and between the layers.

The Digital Map Model is a basic topological model that is extended with other functional parts of the digital twin and connects them all: configuration, maintenance, assurance (KPIs, status, health, symptoms), traffic engineering, different behaviours and actions, simulation, emulation, mathematical abstractions, AI algorithms, etc.

The Digital Map Data consists of virtual instances of network and service topologies at different layers. The Digital Map provides the access to this data via standard API for both read and write, with query capabilities and links to other YANG modules (SAIN, SAP, Inventory, Assets, …) and non-YANG mode.

section.name: Why Digital Map?
section.t:
One of the important requirements for the Digitalization and Digital Twin is to correlate all models and data to topological entities at different layers in the layered twin network. This draft proposes A Digital Map Model as a basis for the Digitalization and Digital Twin. The Digital Map would provide a virtual instance of the topological information of the network, based on this Digital Map Model. The Digital Map is the first step towards the Digital Twin.
The Digital Map Model and Data will provide this missing correlation between the topology models and data and all other models and data: KPIs, alarms, incidents, inventory (with UUIDs), configuration, traffic engineering, planning (what if), simulation, emulations, actions, behaviours.
Some of these models and data are in the context of device, some in context of network or subnetwork and some in context of customer services, needed for both inner and outer closed-loops.
Therefore, Digital Map is needed to break down data islands and have a digital twin for simulation and closed loop, which is required to solve autonomous networking.
The following are some use cases that require Digital Map:

ul.li: Generic Inventory Queries
o Service-> subservice -> resource
o Resource -> subservice -> service
Intent/Service Assurance
Service E2E and Per-Link KPIs on the digital map (delay, jitter, loss)
Capacity Planning
Simulation
Closed Loop

section.name: Other Related IETF Activities
section.t: The following standards are core for the Digital Map.

ul.li: IETF Network Model and Network Topology Model
A YANG Grouping for Geographic Location
IETF Modules that augment for differenet technologies:
o A YANG Data Model for Traffic Engineering (TE) Topologies
o A YANG Data Model for Layer 2 Network Topologies
o A YANG Data Model for OSFP Topology
o A YANG Data Model for IS-IS Topology

section.t: The Digital Map may need to link to the following models, some are already augmenting , we need further investigation for each of these items:

ul.li: Service Access Point (SAP) , augments 'ietf-network' data model by adding the SAP inventory
SAIN and
An Inventory Management Model for Enterprise Networks augments 'ietf-network-topology' with inventory information for node, link and termination-point. It also has UUIDs.
Data Model for Lifecycle Management and Operations
KPIs: delay, jitter, loss
Attachement Circuits (ACs) and
Configuration: L2SM , L3SM , L2NM , L3NM
Incident Management for Network Services
Transaction ID
Etc?

section.name: Digital Map Requirements
section.t: The following are the core requirements for the Digital Map:

ol.li: Basic model with Network, Node, Link, Interface
Layered Digital Map, from physical network up to customer service and intent

Open and Programmable Digital Map. This includes read / Write for Digital Map (write important for future simulations and what if scenarios). Doing what-if analysis requires the ability to take snapshots and to switch easily between them. Because we have to distinguish between a change on the digital map for future simulation and a change that reflects the current reality of the network.

Standard based Digital Map Models and APIs (e.g. based on IETF Network Topology). Digital Map must provide the standards APIs that provide for Read / Write and queries. This API must also provide the capability to retrieve the links to external data / models.
Digital Map Models and APIs must be common over different network domains
Digital Map must be multi-vendor
Digital Map must provide semantics for layered network topologies and for linking external models/data
Digital Map must provide inter-layer and between layer relationships
Digital Map must be extensible with meta data

Digital Map must be pluggable a) We must connect to other YANG modules for Configuration, Inventory, Intent Assurance (SAIN), etc b) Not everything can be in YANG, we need to connect Digital Map YANG model with other modelling mechanisms, both southbound, northbound and internally

Digital Map must be optimized for graph traversal for paths. This means that only providing link nodes and source and sink relationships to termination-points may not be sufficient, we may need to have the direct relationship between the termination points or nodes

section.t: The requirements [1-6] are automatically fulfilled with RFC8345 and extensions. The requirements [7-8] are partially fulfiled, there may be need for some additional semantics. The requirements [9-11] will need some extensions to the RFC8345. In some cases for [10], the links are already sone by augmenting 'ietf-network' and 'ietf-network-topology'. For others, we need to add some mechanims to link the models and data.
The following are the scope requirements for the Digital Map:

ol.li: Digital Map should contain only topological information
Digital Map entities should contain only properties used to identify topological entities at different layers, identify their roles and topological relationships between them
Digital Map should contain only topological relationships inside each layer or between the layers (underlay/overlay)
Digital Map should only have links to other functional Digital Twin data and models.
ACLs and Route Policies will be outside of the digital map, they would be linked to digital map
Dynamic paths may either be outside of the digital map, part of traffic engineering data/models
Provide capability for conditional retrieval of parts of digital map
Must support geo-spatial, temporal, and historical data

section.t: The following are the arch requirements for the Digital Map:

ol.li: Scale, performance, integration
Initial discovery and dynamic (change only) synch

section.name: How to augment for generic Digital Map extensions
section.t: Approaches that we can take

section.name: How to augment for new technologies / layers
section.t: Some guidelines and maybe example in the Anex Also, how the existing augmentation work with Digital Map?

section.name: What is not in the basic model
section.t: The following are the extensions needed for Digital Map modelling and APIs:

ul.li: Bidirectional links
Multi-point connectivity (hub and spoke, full mesh, complex)
We may need additional supporting relationships: supporting for TP->Node, supporting for Node->Network
More Network-related semantic is needed, for example:
We modelled Tunnels ad Paths via but we lost some semantics that is in RFC8795
We modelled all relationships via supporting, maybe extend with how underlay is done in RFC8795
Relationship Properties
Subtypes
Layers/ sub-layers
Some common roles: primary, backup, aggregation, hub, spoke

section.name: Open issues for further analysis
section.t: The following are the open issues that need further analysis:

ul.li: Do we need separation of L2 and L3 topologies?
Do we need sublayers as well? Layers versus sublayers? E.g. Routing versus OSPF, IS-IS
Same technology at service versus underlay? BGP per VPN vs common BGP shared between multiple VPNs. Different layers, same model, relationship define the layer.

section.name: How to connect to the external world
section.t: How to connect to other YANG modules
How to connect YANG models with other modelling mechanisms

section.name: Digital Map APIs
section.t: This will include hierarchical APIs for cross-domain figure, IETF YANG Based API (read and write, change subscription and notify) and Query API

section.name: Digital Map Knowledge
section.t: The following knowledge was needed to build digital map:

ul.li: Abstract IETF Entities and Relationships as in
Augmentations for a)Layers/sublayers b)Entities (services and subservices), c)Properties
Rules for aggregating entities
Rules for instantiating relationships Relationships (inter-layer and intra-layer)
Mapping from devices and controllers

section.t: What can be achieved with existing RFC8345 YANG:

ul.li: Entities (base class IETF Network, IETF Node, IETF Link, IETF TP)
Properties
Relationships

section.t: Next steps

ul.li: How to add temporal
How to add spacial
How to add historical

section.name: Conclusions
section.t: Digital Map Modelling and Data are basis for the Digital Twin. During our PoC we have proven that Digital Map can be modelled using . Nevertheless, we proposed some extensions/augmentations to to support Digital Maps. There must be some constraints in regards to how to augment the core Digital Map model for different Layers and Technologies in order to support the approach in our PoC. All entities must augment IETF node, IETF network, IETF link or IETF Termination Point and augmentation can only include new properties.
